column1: I remember vividly that evening in Calcutta when the fairy story began. The rain and the storm had been incessant. The whole of the city was flooded. The water was knee-deep in our lane. I had a straining hope
column3: that my tutor would be prevented from coming that evening. I sat on the stool in the far corner of the verandah looking down the lane
column4: with a heart beating faster and faster. Every minute I kept my eye on the rain
column5: and when it began to diminish
column6: I prayed with all my might: "Please
column8: send some more rain till half-past seven is over." For I was quite ready to believe that there was no other need for rain except to protect one helpless boy one evening in one corner of Calcutta from the deadly clutches of his tutor. If not in answer to my prayer
column9: at any rate according to some grosser law of nature
column10: the rain did not give up.
